Award.AwardTitle: LSCBR: Operational Support for the Ambystoma Genetic Stock Center
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support continued operation of the living collection of Ambystoma mexicanum, commonly called the axlotyl at the University of Kentucky. The collection, originally established many decades ago at IU, is a historically significant resource that provides animals used actively and widely in biological research. The ongoing development of genome resources for the axolotl and other closely related species is expected to foster continued interest in Ambystoma as a powerful non mammalian vertebrate model system. Most notably, axolotls are studied because they are unique among vertebrates in being able to perfectly regenerate numerous body parts. These include the spinal cord, limbs, jaw, and tail, all of which can be regenerated at any point during embryonic, larval, and adult life. Relocation of the collection to the UKY will consolidate the living stock resource with genome and bioinformatics resources currently being developed for the Ambystoma research community. The collection will not only continue to enable traditional research areas where the axolotl is the best vertebrate model system, it will also continue to take an active role in facilitating use of the organism in K-12 education and public outreach efforts.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) provided 10 years of support for the Ambystoma Genetic Stock Center (AGSC) at the University of Kentucky. This support was used to sustain and distribute living stocks of Mexican axolotls (Ambystoma mexicanum) from a collection that was first established in the 1930's. The AGSC is the primary distributor of axolotls that are used in scientific studies. The axolotl is seeing increased use in basic and biomedical research and significant impacts are anticipated into the future, especially in the area of tissue regeneration. Axolotls are unique in their ability to regenerate limbs, spinal cord, and even brain tissue. The axololt continues to be the focus of genomic and genetic resource development; in just the past few years, several significant resources were developed including a meiotic map, gene expression databases, and bacterial artificial chromosome libraries. These resources are being used to establish the orthology of axolotl and human genes, detail gene expression during tissue regeneration, and make transgenic and mutant axolotls. Also, a novel, laser chromosome capture approach is being used to sequence the formidable axolotl genome, which is 10x larger than the human genome. During the past 10 years, approximately 3,500 orders were shipped to hundreds of research and educational institutions, supplying over 200,000 embryos, larvae, juveniles, and adults. In addition to supplying wildtype axolotls and several historical mutants (albino, white, melanoid, axanthic, cardiac, shortoes, eyeless), the AGSC also shipped transgenics that expressed green and red fluorescent proteins. NSF funding for the AGSC ended May 31, 2015. The AGSC is currently funded by the National Institutes of Health. 


Last Modified: 06/17/2015
Modified by: Stephen R Voss
